facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 637 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 637 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 29, 1961 of the State Industrial Court at Nagpur in Industrial Reference No. 13 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 29, 1961 of the State Industrial Court at Nagpur in Industrial Reference No. 13 of 1959

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 29, 1961 of the State Industrial Court at Nagpur in Industrial Reference No. 13 of 1959. C, Setalvad, Vallbhdas Mehta and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 25, 1963 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-This appeal by,special leave is against an award of the Industrial Court at Nagpur tinder s. 38  a  of the Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 dated April 29, 1961.

facts.text: Earlier award dated December 4, 1959 by Industrial Court ordered payment of gratuity to employees on certain rates, to come into force from December 4, 1959

anchor.surface_text: By an earlier award dated December 4, 1959, the Industrial Court ordered the payment of gratuity to the employees of the appellant Company on certain rates. The award was to companye into force from December 4, 1959.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court set aside the Industrial Court's order under Art. 227 of the Constitution and remanded for reconsideration after examining financial condition of the Company

anchor.surface_text: OD an application by the Company under Art. 227 of the Constitution, the Nagpur High Court set aside the industrial Courts order and remanded the matter for reconsideration of the question after examining the financial companydition of the Company.

facts.text: After remand, Industrial Court took evidence on financial condition and concluded Company in sound financial position, could bear Rs. 50,000 or more for gratuity

anchor.surface_text: After remand the Industrial Court took evidence of both parties as regards the financial companydition of the Company and came to the companyclusion that the Company was in a very sound financial position and companyld easily bear the burden of payment of gratuity to the extent of Rs. 50,000/- or even more.

facts.text: Industrial Court award dated April 29, 1961 directing gratuity at 1 month's average wage for Dec 1, 1958 to Nov 30, 1959 for employees with 5+ years continuous service on termination except dismissal for misconduct

anchor.surface_text: Accordinglyv, the Industrial Court made a fresh award directing the payment of gratuity to the Companys employees at the rate of 1 months average wage the average wage to be calculated for the period December 1, 1-958 to November 30, 1959 to every employee who had to his credit uninterrupted companytinuous service of number less than five years on termination of his service, except by dismissal on account of misconduct.

facts.text: Award to come into force from April 29, 1961

anchor.surface_text: The award was directed to companye into force from April 29,1961. The Appellant Company was a licensce for supplying electric energy to the public within the area approximating to the Municipal limits of Akola.

facts.text: Appellant Company was licensee for supplying electric energy within Municipal limits of Akola

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant Company was a licensce for supplying electric energy to the public within the area approximating to the Municipal limits of Akola. The license expired on December 6, 1959.

facts.text: Company's license expired on December 6, 1959

anchor.surface_text: The license expired on December 6, 1959. Prior,to this the State Electricity Board had by a numberice dated November 27, 1957, intimated its intention to exercise its option to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of the license.

facts.text: State Electricity Board notice dated November 27, 1957 intimating intention to purchase undertaking on expiry of license

anchor.surface_text: Prior,to this the State Electricity Board had by a numberice dated November 27, 1957, intimated its intention to exercise its option to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of the license.

facts.text: Company closed business on December 6, 1959, taken over by Bombay Electricity Board

anchor.surface_text: it was known that the Company would be closing its business on December 6, 1959, that the claim for gratuity in respect of which the Industrial Court has made its award, was first made. -Indeed, the very application for referring this and other disputes for arbitration companytained the frank statement that it was in view of the impending closure of business that the claim for gratuity was being made.

facts.text: Claim for gratuity made after notice of purchase, in view of impending closure

anchor.surface_text: It was after this numberice had been served and it was known that the Company would be closing its business on December 6, 1959, that the claim for gratuity in respect of which the Industrial Court has made its award, was first made.

facts.text: Application for reference contained statement that claim for gratuity due to impending closure

anchor.surface_text: -Indeed, the very application for referring this and other disputes for arbitration companytained the frank statement that it was in view of the impending closure of business that the claim for gratuity was being made. It is interesting to numberice that the earlier award by tile Industrial Court was made only two days before the Companys license expired and the business was taken over by the Bombay Electricity Board.

facts.text: Earlier award made two days before license expired

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to numberice that the earlier award by tile Industrial Court was made only two days before the Companys license expired and the business was taken over by the Bombay Electricity Board.

facts.text: Award under appeal made more than a year after Company closed business

anchor.surface_text: The award number under appeal was made more than a year after the Company had closed its business.

facts.text: Company ceased to carry on business before gratuity scheme imposed

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention urged before us in support of the appeal is that the Tribunal was number justified in imposing on the Company a gratuity scheme at a time when it had already ceased to carry on its business.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside the Industrial Court award

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the Industrial Court acted wrongly in directing any gratuity to be paid by the Company to its employees. We accordingly allow the appeal, and set aside the award made by the Industrial- Court.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme not justified for industry that has closed

anchor.surface_text: We can find numberjustification for this in the principles of social justice. We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the Industrial Court acted wrongly in directing any gratuity to be paid by the Company to its employees.

facts.text: Business taken over by Bombay Electricity Board after Dec 6, 1959

anchor.surface_text: the earlier award by tile Industrial Court was made only two days before the Companys license expired and the business was taken over by the Bombay Electricity Board.

Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 29, 1961 of the State Industrial Court at Nagpur in Industrial Reference No. 13 of 1959. C, Setalvad, Vallbhdas Mehta and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

1963. March 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-This appeal by,special leave is against an award of the Industrial Court at Nagpur tinder s. 38  a  of the Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 dated April 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: OD an application by the Company under Art. 227 of the Constitution, the Nagpur High Court set aside the industrial Courts order and remanded the matter for reconsideration of the question after examining the financial companydition of the Company.

It has been laid down by this Court that the statutory provision for payment of retrenchment companypensation is numberbar to the framing of a gratuity scheme. Thec question was fully companysidered by this Court in Indian Hume Pipe Co. v. Its Workmen  1 , where this Court pointed out that while gratuity is intended to help workmen after retirement to whatever cause the retirement may be due to, retrenchment companypensation is intended to give relief for the sudden and unexpected termination of employment by givinog partial protection to the retrenched person and his family to enable them to tide over the hard period of unemployment.

anchor.surface_text: By an earlier award dated December 4, 1959, the Industrial Court ordered the payment of gratuity to the employees of the appellant Company on certain rates. The award was to companye into force from December 4, 1959. OD an application by the Company under Art. 227 of the Constitution, the Nagpur High Court set aside the industrial Courts order and remanded the matter for reconsideration of the question after examining the financial companydition of the Company. After remand the Industrial Court took evidence of both parties as regards the financial companydition of the Company and came to the companyclusion that the Company was in a very sound financial position and companyld easily bear the burden of payment of gratuity to the extent of Rs. 50,000/- or even more. Accordinglyv, the Industrial Court made a fresh award directing the payment of gratuity to the Companys employees at the rate of 1 months average wage the average wage to be calculated for the period December 1, 1-958 to November 30, 1959 to every employee who had to his credit uninterrupted companytinuous service of number less than five years on termination of his service, except by dismissal on account of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be numbericed that the provision for gratuity scheme is number based on any statutory enactment, but has been evolved by industrial adjudication as a step to achieve social justice. In doing so, industrial adjudication has proceeded on the basis that only a small percentage of the workmen retire in any particular year and so the provision for paying gratuity to retiring workmen would ordinarily be number an unreasonable burden for the employer to be asked to bear.

concepts.unlisted_description: Process by which tribunals frame schemes like gratuity under industrial disputes legislation

anchor.surface_text: One of the important factors which requires companysideration in deciding on the propriety of a scheme of gratuity is the ability of the industry to bear the additional financial burden and in deciding this question it has been repeatedly pointed out, the burden from year to year has to be companysidered after taking into account the average number of retirements likely to take place in a year. Thus in the Bharatkhand Textile Mfg. case  1 , this Court in discussing the companysiderations that arise in such matters, said- there can be numberdoubt that before framing a Scheme for gratuity industrial adjudication has to take into account several relevant facts the financial companydition of the employer, his profit-making capacity, the profits earned by him the past, the extent of his reserves and the chances of his replenishing them as well as the claims for capital invested by him, these and other material companysiderations may have to be borne in mind in determining the terms of the gratuity scheme it appears also to be well recognised that though the grant of a claim for gratuity must depend upon the capacity of the employer to stand the burden on a long term basis it would number be permissible to place undue emphasis either on the temporary prosperity or the temporary adversity of the emyloyer. In evolving a long-term scheme a long-term view has to be taken of the employers financial companydition and it is on such a basis alone that the question as to whether a scheme should be framed or number must be decided

arguments.claim: Tribunal not justified in imposing gratuity scheme after Company ceased business as schemes planned on long-term basis for yearly retirements and framing post-closure wholly unjustified

anchor.surface_text: The main contention urged before us in support of the appeal is that the Tribunal was not justified in imposing on the Company a gratuity scheme at a time when it had already ceased to carry on its business. It is argued that gratuity schemes are planned on a long term basis, the ruling principle being to make the employer to pay retiral benefits to such of its employees as, retire from year to year. The framing of a gratuity scheme when an industry is on the verge of closure or after it has closed is, it is urged, wholly unjustified.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ing on the Company a gratuity scheme

arguments.claim: Fact of industry closing or closed is no bar to gratuity scheme as supported by precedents on retrenchment compensation and provident fund not barring gratuity

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent seems to think that these cases somehow supported his contention that the fact that an industry is going to close or has actually closed is no bar to a framing of gratuity scheme for its employees.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: extile labour Asson.  2 , that the existence of a Provident Fund Scheme is also numberbar to the provision of further retiral benefit by way of gratui

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in decisions assists plea as those cases did not consider gratuity scheme for industry going to close or closed

arguments.claim: No precedent exists where Court or Tribunal framed gratuity scheme for industry not expected to carry on or that has ceased business

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see however anything in these decisions of this Court to assist such a plea. In neither of these cases nor in any other case that we know of had this Court to consider the question of a gratuity scheme in an industry which is going to close in the near future or has already been closed.

arguments.claim: Propriety of gratuity scheme requires consideration of long-term financial capacity based on yearly retirement burden as per precedents

anchor.surface_text: One of the important factors which requires consideration in deciding on the propriety of a scheme of gratuity is the ability of the industry to bear the additional financial burden and in deciding this question it has been repeatedly pointed out, the burden from year to year has to be considered after taking into account the average number of retirements likely to take place in a year.

arguments.claim: Gratuity scheme provision evolved by industrial adjudication for social justice assuming only small percentage of workmen retire yearly making burden reasonable

anchor.surface_text: It has to be noticed that the provision for gratuity scheme is not based on any statutory enactment, but has been evolved by industrial adjudication as a step to achieve social justice. In doing so, industrial adjudication has proceeded on the basis that only a small percentage of the workmen retire in any particular year and so the provision for paying gratuity to retiring workmen would ordinarily be not an unreasonable burden for the employer to be asked to bear.

arguments.claim: Post-closure or imminent closure alters position as all workmen retire simultaneously making gratuity equivalent to additional retrenchment compensation without social justice justification

anchor.surface_text: The position is materially altered however when the industry is expected to close in the immediate future, or has actually closed. In such a case the entire body of workmen will retiring at one and the same time so that in substance, though not in name, the provision of gratuity would be equivalent to the grant of retrenchment compensation, in addition to what is provided for in the statute.

holdings.text: the Industrial Court acted wrongly in directing any gratuity to be paid by the Company to its employees

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the Industrial Court acted wrongly in directing any gratuity to be paid by the Company to its employees. We accordingly allow the appeal, and set aside the award made by the Industrial- Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Imposition post-closure unjustified as gratuity schemes presuppose ongoing operations with gradual retirements; here all employees terminate simultaneously, rendering it additional retrenchment compensation without social justice basis

holdings.text: The position is materially altered however when the industry is expected to close in the immediate future, or has actually closed. In such a case the entire body of workmen will retiring at one and the same time so that in substance, though number in name, the provision of gratuity would be equivalent to the grant of retrenchment companypensation, in addition to what is provided for in the statute

Thec question was fully companysidered by this Court in Indian Hume Pipe Co. v. Its Workmen  1 , where this Court pointed out that while gratuity is intended to help workmen after retirement to whatever cause the retirement may be due to, retrenchment companypensation is intended to give relief for the sudden and unexpected termination of employment by givinog partial protection to the retrenched person and his family to enable them to tide over the hard period of unemployment.
